description: From French impersonnel, from Latin impersōnālis, from im- (“not”) + persōnālis (“personal”).

adjectives.description: impersonal (comparative more impersonal, superlative most impersonal)

entries.meaning: Not personal; not representing a person; not having personality.
examples: The great tragedians of Greece reveal to us their people's exquisite sense of beauty, and their faith in an awful, an almighty, but an impersonal power, called Fate
She sounded impersonal as she gave her report of the Nazi death camps.

entries.meaning: (grammar, of a verb or other word) Not having a subject, or having a third person pronoun without an antecedent.
examples: The verb “rain” is impersonal in sentences like “It’s raining.”
